elements.content: In this work, we systematically report four indium–organic framework (InOF) crystals, which comprise the In(CO2)4 monomer for [InCu(inc)4](NO3) (InOF-5) and [Me2NH2]2[In2(Cu4I4)(pdc)4] (InOF-6), the In(OH)(CO2)2 chain for [In2(Cu4I4)(OH)2(nia)4] (InOF-7), and In3O(CO2)6 clusters for [(In3O)2(Cu4I4)3(nia)12(H2O)6](NO3)2 (InOF-8). With the help of the ligand-oriented bifunctional method, a series of novel heterometallic indium–organic frameworks can be easily achieved through the way the pyridyl N-affinitive sites connect to Cu-based units and the COO–-affinitive sites to In(III) centers. This new strategy will open the door to the construction of multifunctional and heterometallic InOF materials.
elements.clean_text: In this work, we systematically report four indium-organic framework (InOF) crystals, which comprise the In(CO2)4 monomer for [InCu(inc)4](NO3) (InOF-5) and [Me2NH2]2[In2(Cu4I4)(pdc)4] (InOF-6), the In(OH)(CO2)2 chain for [In2(Cu4I4)(OH)2(nia)4] (InOF-7), and In3O(CO2)6 clusters for [(In3O)2(Cu4I4)3(nia)12(H2O)6](NO3)2 (InOF-8). With the help of the ligand-oriented bifunctional method, a series of novel heterometallic indium-organic frameworks can be easily achieved through the way the pyridyl N-affinitive sites connect to Cu-based units and the COO--affinitive sites to In(III) centers. This new strategy will open the door to the construction of multifunctional and heterometallic InOF materials.

elements.content: With the help of the ligand-oriented bifunctional method, the construction of heterometallic indium−organic frameworks (InOFs) can be easily achieved through the way the N-affinitive sites connect to Cu-based units and the COO−-affinitive sites to In(III) centers. We have successfully embedded functional units in a porous InOF system. This new strategy is greatly important and will open a door to the construction of multifunctional and highly porous metal−organic framework materials.
elements.clean_text: With the help of the ligand-oriented bifunctional method, the construction of heterometallic indium-organic frameworks (InOFs) can be easily achieved through the way the N-affinitive sites connect to Cu-based units and the COO--affinitive sites to In(III) centers. We have successfully embedded functional units in a porous InOF system. This new strategy is greatly important and will open a door to the construction of multifunctional and highly porous metal-organic framework materials.

elements.content: In recent years, multifunctional metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) are recognized as porous organic–inorganic hybrid materials for many potential applications in carbon dioxide storage, hydrogen energy, hydrocarbon filtration, and drug transmission. Generally, we have deemed MOF materials to be a versatile platform as they are known for their well-refined structures and tunable and functional pore environments. Therefore, MOF chemists have been trying to design and prepare novel materials with various organic ligands and inorganic metal units. Very recently, the so-called postsynthetic method and transmetalation method have been extensively used to synthesize the isostructural frameworks with well-preserved crystallinity, high porosity, and structural characteristics of the original structure. Among all metal ions, high-coordination-number In(III) ions tend to generate structurally stable and appealing frameworks that are suitable for conducting further applications. Unfortunately, these two methods do not work well in porous indium–organic frameworks (InOFs) because of their unsuitability and incompatibility.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

In recent years, multifunctional metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) are recognized as porous organic-inorganic hybrid materials for many potential applications in carbon dioxide storage, hydrogen energy, hydrocarbon filtration, and drug transmission. Generally, we have deemed MOF materials to be a versatile platform as they are known for their well-refined structures and tunable and functional pore environments. Therefore, MOF chemists have been trying to design and prepare novel materials with various organic ligands and inorganic metal units. Very recently, the so-called postsynthetic method and transmetalation method have been extensively used to synthesize the isostructural frameworks with well-preserved crystallinity, high porosity, and structural characteristics of the original structure. Among all metal ions, high-coordination-number In(III) ions tend to generate structurally stable and appealing frameworks that are suitable for conducting further applications. Unfortunately, these two methods do not work well in porous indium-organic frameworks (InOFs) because of their unsuitability and incompatibility.

elements.content: Experimentally speaking, we would like to select carboxylate linkers to obtain functional InOF materials because of their COO–-affinitive In(III) centers. In this context, new methods need to be developed for novel InOF structures, which might be further applied to other MOF chemistry. Previously, our group reported one structure incorporating four types of zinc-based secondary building units (SBUs), which indicates it might be an effective way to embed diverse indium-based SBUs in InOF materials. However, throughout the CCDC database and the literature, In(III) centers usually form only three common and typical kinds of SBU-based architectures, including In(CO2)4 monomers, In(OH)(CO2)2 chains, and In3O(CO2)6 trimers. Therefore, setting up a novel approach for the design and construction of functional InOF materials still requires effort.
elements.clean_text: Experimentally speaking, we would like to select carboxylate linkers to obtain functional InOF materials because of their COO--affinitive In(III) centers. In this context, new methods need to be developed for novel InOF structures, which might be further applied to other MOF chemistry. Previously, our group reported one structure incorporating four types of zinc-based secondary building units (SBUs), which indicates it might be an effective way to embed diverse indium-based SBUs in InOF materials. However, throughout the CCDC database and the literature, In(III) centers usually form only three common and typical kinds of SBU-based architectures, including In(CO2)4 monomers, In(OH)(CO2)2 chains, and In3O(CO2)6 trimers. Therefore, setting up a novel approach for the design and construction of functional InOF materials still requires effort.

<title>Synthetic Strategy
for Constructing Heterometallic Indium–Organic
Framework Materials by the Bifunctional Method</title>
</caption>
<graphic id="gr1" orientation="portrait" position="float" xlink:href="cg-2014-01795w_0006.tif"></graphic>

elements.clean_text: 1  Synthetic Strategy for Constructing Heterometallic Indium-Organic Framework Materials by the Bifunctional Method

elements.content: By using the ligand-oriented bifunctional method in which COO–-affinitive metallic ions bind to only carboxylate groups while the N-affinitive metallic ions bind to only pyridyl N-centers based on the bifunctional ligands (Scheme ), we were able to synthesize intriguing heterometallic structures that are essentially derived from the different affinity between various metallic ions with N/O-donor centers. In this case, all the COO–-affinitive In(III) ions coordinate to only carboxylate groups, whereas N-affinitive Cu(I)-based units bind to only pyridyl N-centers. In this work, we systematically present four novel single-crystal heterometallic InOF structures for the first time, including the In(CO2)4 monomer (InOF-5 and -6), an infinite In(OH)(CO2)2 chain for InOF-7, and In3O(CO2)6 clusters for InOF-8. Moreover, a low-pressure region single-component gas sorption experiment has also been performed.
elements.clean_text: By using the ligand-oriented bifunctional method in which COO--affinitive metallic ions bind to only carboxylate groups while the N-affinitive metallic ions bind to only pyridyl N-centers based on the bifunctional ligands (Scheme ), we were able to synthesize intriguing heterometallic structures that are essentially derived from the different affinity between various metallic ions with N/O-donor centers. In this case, all the COO--affinitive In(III) ions coordinate to only carboxylate groups, whereas N-affinitive Cu(I)-based units bind to only pyridyl N-centers. In this work, we systematically present four novel single-crystal heterometallic InOF structures for the first time, including the In(CO2)4 monomer (InOF-5 and -6), an infinite In(OH)(CO2)2 chain for InOF-7, and In3O(CO2)6 clusters for InOF-8. Moreover, a low-pressure region single-component gas sorption experiment has also been performed.

elements.content: All the reactions were conducted in an autoclave under autogenous pressure. Reagent-grade-quality reactants and solvents from commercial sources were used without further purification. Powder X-ray diffraction patterns were collected with a Rigaku DMAX 2500 X-ray diffractometer by using Cu Kα radiation (λ = 0.154 nm). Elemental analyses (C, H, and N) were conducted on a German Elementary Vario EL III instrument. Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were conducted on a NETZSCH STA 449C thermal analyzer under a flowing nitrogen atmosphere at a rate of 10 °C/min. Moreover, single-component gas measurements were performed with an Accelerated Surface Area and Porosimetry 2020 (ASAP2020) surface area analyzer.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Measurements

All the reactions were conducted in an autoclave under autogenous pressure. Reagent-grade-quality reactants and solvents from commercial sources were used without further purification. Powder X-ray diffraction patterns were collected with a Rigaku DMAX 2500 X-ray diffractometer by using Cu Kα radiation (λ = 0.154 nm). Elemental analyses (C, H, and N) were conducted on a German Elementary Vario EL III instrument. Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were conducted on a NETZSCH STA 449C thermal analyzer under a flowing nitrogen atmosphere at a rate of 10 °C/min. Moreover, single-component gas measurements were performed with an Accelerated Surface Area and Porosimetry 2020 (ASAP2020) surface area analyzer.

elements.content: A mixture of In(NO3)3 (0.10 mmol, 33 mg), CuI (0.20 mmol, 38 mg), and Hnic (0.20 mmol, 25 mg, Hnic = isonicotinic acid) in an N,N′-dimethylacetamide (DMA, 3 mL)/MeCN (3 mL) mixed solvent was sealed in an autoclave, which was heated at 120 °C for 3 days and cooled to room temperature. Single-crystal electron paramagnetic resonance data confirmed the Cu(II) ions in the framework formulation of [InCu(inc)4](NO3) (Figure S12 of the ). After being washed with fresh MeCN, the orange crystals were obtained in ∼55% yield based on the Hnic ligand. Elemental analysis was conducted for InOF-5: C, 41.64%; H, 3.19%; N, 10.88%. Found: C, 41.58%; H, 3.12%; N, 10.41%. Finally, the phase purity of the sample was confirmed by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) (Figure S13 of the ).
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of [InCu(inc)4](NO3)⋅0.5MeCN⋅DMA (InOF-5)

A mixture of In(NO3)3 (0.10 mmol, 33 mg), CuI (0.20 mmol, 38 mg), and Hnic (0.20 mmol, 25 mg, Hnic = isonicotinic acid) in an N,N'-dimethylacetamide (DMA, 3 mL)/MeCN (3 mL) mixed solvent was sealed in an autoclave, which was heated at 120 °C for 3 days and cooled to room temperature. Single-crystal electron paramagnetic resonance data confirmed the Cu(II) ions in the framework formulation of [InCu(inc)4](NO3) (Figure S12 of the ). After being washed with fresh MeCN, the orange crystals were obtained in ~55% yield based on the Hnic ligand. Elemental analysis was conducted for InOF-5: C, 41.64%; H, 3.19%; N, 10.88%. Found: C, 41.58%; H, 3.12%; N, 10.41%. Finally, the phase purity of the sample was confirmed by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) (Figure S13 of the ).

elements.content: A mixture of InCl3 (0.10 mmol, 23 mg), CuI (0.20 mmol, 38 mg), and H2pdc (0.10 mmol, 17 mg, H2pdc = 3,5-pyridinedicarboxylic acid) in a DMA (3 mL)/N,N′-dimethylpropyleneurea (DMPU, 2 mL)/1,4-dioxane (2 mL) mixed solvent was sealed in a 23 mL glass vial, which was heated at 120 °C for 4 days and cooled to room temperature. As for the charge equilibrium, the DMA solvent molecules were decomposed into disordered Me2NH2 + cations during the reaction. After being washed with fresh MeCN, the light yellow crystals were obtained in ∼40% yield based on the H2pdc ligand. Elemental analysis was conducted for InOF-6: C, 23.43%; H, 1.95%; N, 5.20%. Found: C, 23.48%; H, 2.04%; N, 5.16%. The phase purity was confirmed by PXRD (Figure S13 of the ).
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of [Me2NH2]2[In2(Cu4I4)(pdc)4]⋅0.25Dioxane⋅0.25DMA⋅0.25DMPU (InOF-6)

A mixture of InCl3 (0.10 mmol, 23 mg), CuI (0.20 mmol, 38 mg), and H2pdc (0.10 mmol, 17 mg, H2pdc = 3,5-pyridinedicarboxylic acid) in a DMA (3 mL)/N,N'-dimethylpropyleneurea (DMPU, 2 mL)/1,4-dioxane (2 mL) mixed solvent was sealed in a 23 mL glass vial, which was heated at 120 °C for 4 days and cooled to room temperature. As for the charge equilibrium, the DMA solvent molecules were decomposed into disordered Me2NH2 + cations during the reaction. After being washed with fresh MeCN, the light yellow crystals were obtained in ~40% yield based on the H2pdc ligand. Elemental analysis was conducted for InOF-6: C, 23.43%; H, 1.95%; N, 5.20%. Found: C, 23.48%; H, 2.04%; N, 5.16%. The phase purity was confirmed by PXRD (Figure S13 of the ).

elements.content: A mixture of In(NO3)3 (0.10 mmol, 33 mg), CuI (0.20 mmol, 38 mg), and Hnia (0.40 mmol, 49 mg, Hnia = nicotinic acid) in a DMA (3 mL)/EtOH (3 mL) mixed solvent was sealed in an autoclave, which was heated at 120 °C for 7 days and cooled to room temperature. After being washed with fresh MeCN, the colorless crystals were obtained in ∼50% yield based on the organic ligand. Elemental analysis was conducted for InOF-7: C, 22.70%; H, 2.32%; N, 4.14%. Found: C, 22.58%; H, 2.23%; N, 4.16%. The phase purity of the sample was also confirmed by PXRD (Figure S13 of the ).
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of [In2(Cu4I4)(OH)2(nia)4]⋅2EtOH⋅DMA (InOF-7)

A mixture of In(NO3)3 (0.10 mmol, 33 mg), CuI (0.20 mmol, 38 mg), and Hnia (0.40 mmol, 49 mg, Hnia = nicotinic acid) in a DMA (3 mL)/EtOH (3 mL) mixed solvent was sealed in an autoclave, which was heated at 120 °C for 7 days and cooled to room temperature. After being washed with fresh MeCN, the colorless crystals were obtained in ~50% yield based on the organic ligand. Elemental analysis was conducted for InOF-7: C, 22.70%; H, 2.32%; N, 4.14%. Found: C, 22.58%; H, 2.23%; N, 4.16%. The phase purity of the sample was also confirmed by PXRD (Figure S13 of the ).

elements.content: A mixture of In(NO3)3 (0.10 mmol, 33 mg), CuI (0.20 mmol, 38 mg), and Hnia (0.40 mmol, 49 mg) in a DMA (3 mL)/MeCN (3 mL) mixed solvent was sealed in an autoclave, which was heated at 120 °C for 7 days and cooled to room temperature. It is worth noting that there are disordered charge-balancing NO3– anions stored inside the large solvent accessible void, which is squeezed out. After being washed with fresh MeCN, the colorless crystals of InOF-8 were obtained in ∼33% yield based on the organic ligand. Elemental analysis was conducted for InOF-8: C, 22.73%; H, 2.00%; N, 7.16%. Found: C, 22.59%; H, 2.07%; N, 7.20%. The phase purity of the sample was also confirmed by PXRD (Figure S13 of the ).
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of [(In3O)2(Cu4I4)3(nia)12(H2O)6](NO3)2⋅12MeCN⋅DMA (InOF-8)

A mixture of In(NO3)3 (0.10 mmol, 33 mg), CuI (0.20 mmol, 38 mg), and Hnia (0.40 mmol, 49 mg) in a DMA (3 mL)/MeCN (3 mL) mixed solvent was sealed in an autoclave, which was heated at 120 °C for 7 days and cooled to room temperature. It is worth noting that there are disordered charge-balancing NO3- anions stored inside the large solvent accessible void, which is squeezed out. After being washed with fresh MeCN, the colorless crystals of InOF-8 were obtained in ~33% yield based on the organic ligand. Elemental analysis was conducted for InOF-8: C, 22.73%; H, 2.00%; N, 7.16%. Found: C, 22.59%; H, 2.07%; N, 7.20%. The phase purity of the sample was also confirmed by PXRD (Figure S13 of the ).

elements.content: Prior to the gas sorption experiment, all the materials have been acetonitrile-exchanged for 1 week to eliminate the large formamide-type molecules and the solvent was refreshed daily. Approximately 100 mg of MeCN-exchanged InOF-5, InOF-6, InOF-7, and InOF-8 were loaded into the sample basket within the ASAP 2020 system and then degassed under dynamic vacuum below 10 μmHg pressure for at least 10 h to obtain their fully desolvated materials. The solvent-exchanged and activated samples retain relatively well their main frameworks after the solvent exchange and activation process, which are confirmed by their corresponding PXRD test.
elements.clean_text:
Solvent Exchange and Activation Process

Prior to the gas sorption experiment, all the materials have been acetonitrile-exchanged for 1 week to eliminate the large formamide-type molecules and the solvent was refreshed daily. Approximately 100 mg of MeCN-exchanged InOF-5, InOF-6, InOF-7, and InOF-8 were loaded into the sample basket within the ASAP 2020 system and then degassed under dynamic vacuum below 10 μmHg pressure for at least 10 h to obtain their fully desolvated materials. The solvent-exchanged and activated samples retain relatively well their main frameworks after the solvent exchange and activation process, which are confirmed by their corresponding PXRD test.

elements.content: The structural data of InOF-5, InOF-6, InOF-7, and InOF-8 were collected on a SuperNova, Dual, Cu at zero, Atlas diffractometer. The crystals were kept at 99.99(16) K during the collection process. Using Olex2, the structure was determined with the ShelXS structure solution program using direct methods and refined with the ShelXL refinement package using least-squares minimization. Crystallographic data and structure refinement parameters for these four crystals are listed in Table S1 of the . We employed PLATON/SQUEEZE to calculate the contribution to the diffraction from the solvent region and thereby produced a set of solvent-free diffraction intensities. The final formulas were calculated from the SQUEEZE results combined with elemental analysis data and TGA data. More details about the crystallographic studies as well as atomic displacement parameters are given in the as CIF files. Crystallographic data for the structure reported in this paper have been deposited. The following crystal structures have been deposited at the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre and allocated deposition numbers (CCDC Nos.) 998990, 998991, 998992, and 998993 for InOF-5, InOF-6, InOF-7, and InOF-8, respectively. These data can be obtained free of charge via www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif.
elements.clean_text:
Single-Crystal X-ray Crystallography

The structural data of InOF-5, InOF-6, InOF-7, and InOF-8 were collected on a SuperNova, Dual, Cu at zero, Atlas diffractometer. The crystals were kept at 99.99(16) K during the collection process. Using Olex2, the structure was determined with the ShelXS structure solution program using direct methods and refined with the ShelXL refinement package using least-squares minimization. Crystallographic data and structure refinement parameters for these four crystals are listed in Table S1 of the . We employed PLATON/SQUEEZE to calculate the contribution to the diffraction from the solvent region and thereby produced a set of solvent-free diffraction intensities. The final formulas were calculated from the SQUEEZE results combined with elemental analysis data and TGA data. More details about the crystallographic studies as well as atomic displacement parameters are given in the  as CIF files. Crystallographic data for the structure reported in this paper have been deposited. The following crystal structures have been deposited at the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre and allocated deposition numbers (CCDC Nos.) 998990, 998991, 998992, and 998993 for InOF-5, InOF-6, InOF-7, and InOF-8, respectively. These data can be obtained free of charge via www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif.

elements.content: Light orange InOF-5 (Figure a) is crystallized in orthorhombic space group Fddd, and its asymmetric unit constitutes one-quarter of an In(III) ion, one-quarter of a Cu(II) ion, and an inc– ligand with a framework formula of [InCu(inc)4](NO3) when we try to remove guest solvent molecules. In Figure a, each inc– ligand takes its carboxylate group to link a typical 8-coordinated [In(CO2)4] moiety that is stretched out through four carboxylate groups, while it utilizes its pyridyl N-donor center at the opposite position to connect to a 4-coordinated [CuN4] moiety with a slightly distorted tetrahedral coordination geometry where the observed In–O and Cu–N bond lengths are in the range of 2.260–2.301 and 2.029 Å, respectively (Figure S1 of the ).
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

[InCu(inc)4](NO3)⋅0.5MeCN⋅DMA (InOF-5)

Light orange InOF-5 (Figure a) is crystallized in orthorhombic space group Fddd, and its asymmetric unit constitutes one-quarter of an In(III) ion, one-quarter of a Cu(II) ion, and an inc- ligand with a framework formula of [InCu(inc)4](NO3) when we try to remove guest solvent molecules. In Figure a, each inc- ligand takes its carboxylate group to link a typical 8-coordinated [In(CO2)4] moiety that is stretched out through four carboxylate groups, while it utilizes its pyridyl N-donor center at the opposite position to connect to a 4-coordinated [CuN4] moiety with a slightly distorted tetrahedral coordination geometry where the observed In-O and Cu-N bond lengths are in the range of 2.260-2.301 and 2.029 Å, respectively (Figure S1 of the ).

elements.content: In structural terms along the a axis, there are alternately one-dimensional left/right-handed square channels with a 4.0 Å diameter (Figure b), which are arranged in an ordered manner from the [In(CO2)4] moiety to the [CuN4] moiety. As viewed along the b axis, we find that the neighboring In···In/Cu···Cu distance is around 12.2 Å, leaving enough open space for free solvents, interpenetration, or self-penetration (Figure S2 of the ). Moreover, careful examination of the entire structure shows us a 2-fold interpenetrating diamond-type network for InOF-5 with a dramatically reduced accessible volume (Figure c and Figure S3 of the ).
elements.clean_text: In structural terms along the a axis, there are alternately one-dimensional left/right-handed square channels with a 4.0 Å diameter (Figure b), which are arranged in an ordered manner from the [In(CO2)4] moiety to the [CuN4] moiety. As viewed along the b axis, we find that the neighboring In⋅⋅⋅In/Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu distance is around 12.2 Å, leaving enough open space for free solvents, interpenetration, or self-penetration (Figure S2 of the ). Moreover, careful examination of the entire structure shows us a 2-fold interpenetrating diamond-type network for InOF-5 with a dramatically reduced accessible volume (Figure c and Figure S3 of the ).

Summary of Crystal Data and Refinement Results crystal formula of framework space group a (Å) b (Å) c (Å) α, β (deg) γ (deg) V (Å3) InOF-5 [InCu(inc)4](NO3) Fddd 12.2035(3) 22.5755(6) 24.7498(5) 90 90 6818.6(3) InOF-6 [Me2NH2]2[In2(Cu4I4)(pdc)4] I4̅2d 20.338(3) 20.338(3) 18.381(5) 90 90 7603(3) InOF-7 [In2(Cu4I4)(OH)2(nia)4] Fddd 59.030(4) 23.417(2) 16.1795(7) 90 90 22363(3) InOF-8 [(In3O)2(Cu4I4)3(nia)12(H2O)6](NO3)2 P6/mcc 21.9173(4) 21.9173(4) 28.2685(4) 90 120 11760.0(3)

Photographs of single InOF crystals viewed via lab microscopy. (a) Crystals of light orange InOF-5. (b) Crystals of light yellow InOF-6. (c) Crystals of colorless InOF-7. (d) Crystals of colorless InOF-8.
elements.clean_text: 1  Photographs of single InOF crystals viewed via lab microscopy. (a) Crystals of light orange InOF-5. (b) Crystals of light yellow InOF-6. (c) Crystals of colorless InOF-7. (d) Crystals of colorless InOF-8.

elements.content: More importantly, the finding of InOF-5 and its heterometallic framework with 4-connected [In(CO4)2] nodes and 4-connected [CuN4] nodes simultaneously existing is a thrilling development in the deeply explored InOF field, because so many researchers have been dedicated to targeting zeolite-type MOF materials by the use of 4-connected In(III) centers. Although the development of composite inorganic building blocks for InOFs has been realized by previous reports, to the best of our knowledge, InOF-5 is the first example of a three-dimensional porous uninodal heterometallic InOF structure in the CCDC database, which exhibits a moderate sorption performance after a solvent exchange and activation process.
elements.clean_text: More importantly, the finding of InOF-5 and its heterometallic framework with 4-connected [In(CO4)2] nodes and 4-connected [CuN4] nodes simultaneously existing is a thrilling development in the deeply explored InOF field, because so many researchers have been dedicated to targeting zeolite-type MOF materials by the use of 4-connected In(III) centers. Although the development of composite inorganic building blocks for InOFs has been realized by previous reports, to the best of our knowledge, InOF-5 is the first example of a three-dimensional porous uninodal heterometallic InOF structure in the CCDC database, which exhibits a moderate sorption performance after a solvent exchange and activation process.

elements.content: Meanwhile, we then further developed the validity of our bifunctional method in the InOF system by extending from the linear pyridinecarboxylate ligand to other bent pyridinecarboxylate or multicarboxylate ligands. Moreover, with the bulky Cu4I4 cluster being introduced into three-dimensional InOF structures, we successfully solvothermally obtained three kinds of noninterpenetrated cluster-based heterometallic InOF crystals, denoted InOF-6, InOF-7, and InOF-8. Luckily, these three InOF structures embrace all common configurations of indium-based SBUs described above, namely, 8-coordinated In(CO2)4, an infinite InO chain, and a 6-connected In3O cluster. Their structures are separately discussed in detail.
elements.clean_text: Meanwhile, we then further developed the validity of our bifunctional method in the InOF system by extending from the linear pyridinecarboxylate ligand to other bent pyridinecarboxylate or multicarboxylate ligands. Moreover, with the bulky Cu4I4 cluster being introduced into three-dimensional InOF structures, we successfully solvothermally obtained three kinds of noninterpenetrated cluster-based heterometallic InOF crystals, denoted InOF-6, InOF-7, and InOF-8. Luckily, these three InOF structures embrace all common configurations of indium-based SBUs described above, namely, 8-coordinated In(CO2)4, an infinite InO chain, and a 6-connected In3O cluster. Their structures are separately discussed in detail.

elements.content: (a) Asymmetric unit of InOF-5. (b) Small sphere embedded in the one-dimensional channel in InOF-5. (c) Twofold interpenetrating InOF-5 structure view along the a axis.
elements.clean_text: 2  (a) Asymmetric unit of InOF-5. (b) Small sphere embedded in the one-dimensional channel in InOF-5. (c) Twofold interpenetrating InOF-5 structure view along the a axis.

elements.content: For light yellow InOF-6 (Figure b), it is crystallized in tetragonal space group I4̅2d and the asymmetric unit comprises two types of coordination sites in the bifunctional organic ligand (H2pdc), namely, N-donor center (pyridyl N atom) and two carboxylate groups (COO– centers). Very interestingly, through the bifunctional method, it leads to a combination of [Cu4I4N4] moieties and [In(COO)4] moieties in the pdc2– ligand (Figure S4 of the ). In this structure, we assume that the in situ decomposed Me2NH2 + cations existing inside the void are the byproduct of the starting DMA solvent with a framework formula of [Me2NH2]2[In2(Cu4I4)(pdc)4], thus inducing the final charge equilibrium. The observed In–O, Cu–I, and Cu–N bond lengths are in the range of 2.146–2.463, 2.637–2.748, and 2.034 Å, respectively (Figure a).
elements.clean_text: For light yellow InOF-6 (Figure b), it is crystallized in tetragonal space group I4̅2d and the asymmetric unit comprises two types of coordination sites in the bifunctional organic ligand (H2pdc), namely, N-donor center (pyridyl N atom) and two carboxylate groups (COO- centers). Very interestingly, through the bifunctional method, it leads to a combination of [Cu4I4N4] moieties and [In(COO)4] moieties in the pdc2- ligand (Figure S4 of the ). In this structure, we assume that the in situ decomposed Me2NH2 + cations existing inside the void are the byproduct of the starting DMA solvent with a framework formula of [Me2NH2]2[In2(Cu4I4)(pdc)4], thus inducing the final charge equilibrium. The observed In-O, Cu-I, and Cu-N bond lengths are in the range of 2.146-2.463, 2.637-2.748, and 2.034 Å, respectively (Figure a).

elements.content: (a) Asymmetric unit of InOF-6. (b) Cage-based voids. (c) ctn-type framework viewed along the c axis.
elements.clean_text: 3  (a) Asymmetric unit of InOF-6. (b) Cage-based voids. (c) ctn-type framework viewed along the c axis.

elements.content: In topological terms, the integration of the 3-connected planar pdc2– ligands together with the 4-connected tetrahedral Cu4I4 clusters and In(III) ions gives a binodal 3,4-connected ctn-type framework with point symbol {8^3}4{8^6}3 analyzed by TOPOS40 (Figure S5 of the ). In this case, the Cu4I4 nodes and In(III) nodes simultaneously play the roles of topologically equivalent nodes where each [Cu4I4N4] moiety connects to four pyridyl N-donor centers and each [In(COO)4] moiety connects to four carboxylate groups through 3-connected bridging pdc2– ligands to give an extending three-dimensional network. Furthermore, compared to so many 4-connected ZIFs and BIFs that have been extensively exploited and studied, 3,4-connected topologies for InOF structures have attracted much less attention.
elements.clean_text: In topological terms, the integration of the 3-connected planar pdc2- ligands together with the 4-connected tetrahedral Cu4I4 clusters and In(III) ions gives a binodal 3,4-connected ctn-type framework with point symbol {8^3}4{8^6}3 analyzed by TOPOS40 (Figure S5 of the ). In this case, the Cu4I4 nodes and In(III) nodes simultaneously play the roles of topologically equivalent nodes where each [Cu4I4N4] moiety connects to four pyridyl N-donor centers and each [In(COO)4] moiety connects to four carboxylate groups through 3-connected bridging pdc2- ligands to give an extending three-dimensional network. Furthermore, compared to so many 4-connected ZIFs and BIFs that have been extensively exploited and studied, 3,4-connected topologies for InOF structures have attracted much less attention.

elements.content: Although the ctn-type InOF-6 contains no straight channels (Figure c), a large guest accessible pore volume is still available after the removal of guest molecules, and the free volume is calculated to be 4403.7 Å3 per unit cell volume and the potential porosity 58.1% by the PLATON program using the default probe size. Meanwhile, the diameter of the largest sphere that can be implanted in this three-dimensional cage-based framework without surpassing the internal surfaces of frameworks is approximately 5.6 Å, while the outermost I···I distance in the cage-based model is ∼21.7 Å as shown in Figure b. The desolvated material exhibits a quasi-type I N2 isotherm with a saturated uptake of 42.4 cm3 g–1 at 77 K, and its BET, Langmuir surface areas, and specific pore volume are 89.8 m2 g–1, 113.2 m2 g–1, and 0.066 cm3 g–1, respectively (Figure S17 of the ).
elements.clean_text: Although the ctn-type InOF-6 contains no straight channels (Figure c), a large guest accessible pore volume is still available after the removal of guest molecules, and the free volume is calculated to be 4403.7 Å3 per unit cell volume and the potential porosity 58.1% by the PLATON program using the default probe size. Meanwhile, the diameter of the largest sphere that can be implanted in this three-dimensional cage-based framework without surpassing the internal surfaces of frameworks is approximately 5.6 Å, while the outermost I⋅⋅⋅I distance in the cage-based model is ~21.7 Å as shown in Figure b. The desolvated material exhibits a quasi-type I N2 isotherm with a saturated uptake of 42.4 cm3 g-1 at 77 K, and its BET, Langmuir surface areas, and specific pore volume are 89.8 m2 g-1, 113.2 m2 g-1, and 0.066 cm3 g-1, respectively (Figure S17 of the ).

elements.content: (a) Asymmetric unit of InOF-7. (b) One-dimensional channel observed in the complicated InOF-7 framework. (c) Chain–cluster–chain structure.
elements.clean_text: 4  (a) Asymmetric unit of InOF-7. (b) One-dimensional channel observed in the complicated InOF-7 framework. (c) Chain-cluster-chain structure.

elements.content: The structure of InOF-7 is found to be crystallized in orthorhombic space group Fddd, and its asymmetric unit consists of an In(III) ion, half a Cu4I4 cluster, a hydroxide anion, and two nia– ligands (Figure a). Similarly, each bifunctional nia– ligand uses a COO– center to link a 6-coordinated In(III) ion in octahedral surroundings constituting an [In(OH)(CO2)2] moiety (Figure S7 of the ), while it takes the remaining N-donor center to connect to a 4-coordinated Cu(I) comprising a [Cu4I4N4] moiety in a tetrahedral coordination geometry where the observed In–O, Cu–I, and Cu–N bond lengths are in the range of 2.055–2.177, 2.668–2.750, and 2.035–2.057 Å, respectively (Figure a). Finally, the framework formula is a neutral [In2(Cu4I4)(OH)2(nia)4] network.
elements.clean_text: The structure of InOF-7 is found to be crystallized in orthorhombic space group Fddd, and its asymmetric unit consists of an In(III) ion, half a Cu4I4 cluster, a hydroxide anion, and two nia- ligands (Figure a). Similarly, each bifunctional nia- ligand uses a COO- center to link a 6-coordinated In(III) ion in octahedral surroundings constituting an [In(OH)(CO2)2] moiety (Figure S7 of the ), while it takes the remaining N-donor center to connect to a 4-coordinated Cu(I) comprising a [Cu4I4N4] moiety in a tetrahedral coordination geometry where the observed In-O, Cu-I, and Cu-N bond lengths are in the range of 2.055-2.177, 2.668-2.750, and 2.035-2.057 Å, respectively (Figure a). Finally, the framework formula is a neutral [In2(Cu4I4)(OH)2(nia)4] network.

elements.content: By linking the Cu4I4 clusters and μ2-OH– by the bifunctional nia– ligands coordinated with In(III) centers to form an infinite In–OH–In–OH chain running along the c axis, InOF-7 exhibits an overall 3D microporous framework (Figure c). The entire structure possesses one-dimensional narrow rhombus-like channels with an aperture size of 12.9 Å × 12.9 Å into which can be inserted 5.5 Å cylinders (Figure S8 of the ). Meanwhile, another interesting structural characteristic is the chain-by-cluster-by-chain structure constructed from functional tetrahedral Cu4I4 clusters and infinite In(OH)(CO2)2 chains (Figure b). Although not all InO chains are parallel to each other in InOF-7, the shortest distance observed between two neighboring InO chains is approximately 16.2 Å (Figure c). In addition, the pore volume ratio is calculated to be 42.0% [per unit cell volume (22363.0 Å3)]; the total free volume is 9400.6 Å3 after the removal of those redundant guest solvent molecules. After the activation process, the experimental N2 sorption isotherm at 77 K confirms its retention of microporosity with a maximal uptake of 155.3 cm3 g–1. Its BET, Langmuir surface area, and real pore volume are 526.6 m2 g–1, 637.4 m2 g–1, and 0.240 cm3 g–1, respectively (Figure S18 of the ).
elements.clean_text: By linking the Cu4I4 clusters and μ2-OH- by the bifunctional nia- ligands coordinated with In(III) centers to form an infinite In-OH-In-OH chain running along the c axis, InOF-7 exhibits an overall 3D microporous framework (Figure c). The entire structure possesses one-dimensional narrow rhombus-like channels with an aperture size of 12.9 Å × 12.9 Å into which can be inserted 5.5 Å cylinders (Figure S8 of the ). Meanwhile, another interesting structural characteristic is the chain-by-cluster-by-chain structure constructed from functional tetrahedral Cu4I4 clusters and infinite In(OH)(CO2)2 chains (Figure b). Although not all InO chains are parallel to each other in InOF-7, the shortest distance observed between two neighboring InO chains is approximately 16.2 Å (Figure c). In addition, the pore volume ratio is calculated to be 42.0% [per unit cell volume (22363.0 Å3)]; the total free volume is 9400.6 Å3 after the removal of those redundant guest solvent molecules. After the activation process, the experimental N2 sorption isotherm at 77 K confirms its retention of microporosity with a maximal uptake of 155.3 cm3 g-1. Its BET, Langmuir surface area, and real pore volume are 526.6 m2 g-1, 637.4 m2 g-1, and 0.240 cm3 g-1, respectively (Figure S18 of the ).

elements.content: For InOF-8, it is crystallized in trigonal space group P6/mmc. It is the most beautiful and most symmetrical structure of this series of InOF materials (Table ). In its asymmetric unit, there are half an In(III) ion, one-quarter of a Cu4I4 cluster, one nia– ligand, one-sixth of a μ3-O2– anion, and half a terminal water molecule with a positive framework formula of [(In3O)2(Cu4I4)3(nia)12(H2O)6]2+ (Figure a). Each nia– ligand uses a COO– center to link 6-coordinated In(III) ions constituting a 6-connected In3O trimer (Figure S9 of the ), while it takes its N-donor site to join a 4-coordinated Cu(I) comprising a 4-connected [Cu4I4N4] unit where all the In–O, Cu–I, and Cu–N bond lengths are 2.043–2.180, 2.617–2.711, and 2.016 Å, respectively.
elements.clean_text: For InOF-8, it is crystallized in trigonal space group P6/mmc. It is the most beautiful and most symmetrical structure of this series of InOF materials (Table ). In its asymmetric unit, there are half an In(III) ion, one-quarter of a Cu4I4 cluster, one nia- ligand, one-sixth of a μ3-O2- anion, and half a terminal water molecule with a positive framework formula of [(In3O)2(Cu4I4)3(nia)12(H2O)6]2+ (Figure a). Each nia- ligand uses a COO- center to link 6-coordinated In(III) ions constituting a 6-connected In3O trimer (Figure S9 of the ), while it takes its N-donor site to join a 4-coordinated Cu(I) comprising a 4-connected [Cu4I4N4] unit where all the In-O, Cu-I, and Cu-N bond lengths are 2.043-2.180, 2.617-2.711, and 2.016 Å, respectively.

elements.content: (a) Asymmetric unit of InOF-8, (b) ∼4.8 Å cages and ∼18.9 Å channels, and (c) three-dimensional tubular structure.
elements.clean_text: 5  (a) Asymmetric unit of InOF-8, (b) ~4.8 Å cages and ~18.9 Å channels, and (c) three-dimensional tubular structure.

elements.content: In structural terms, InOF-8 showcases one-dimensional hexagonal channels divided by tetrahedral Cu4I4 and [In3O(CO2)6] moieties. The interconnection of six Cu4I4 units and six [In3O(CO2)6] units makes up the cross section of the hexagonal channel with a maximal size of 18.9 Å by the internal edge of two opposite Cu4I4 and 36.1 Å by the external edge of opposite [In3O(CO2)6] forms along the c axis, respectively, as shown in Figure c. There is a small cage-based cavity between two [In3O(CO2)6] moieties along the c axis, which is interconnected by three Cu4I4 clusters, two [In3O(CO2)6] moieties, and six nia– ligands, with a 4.8 Å diameter sphere (Figure b). Therefore, the overall structure of InOF-8 is a highly porous MOF structure in which cages and one-dimensional channels coexist in a cluster-by-cluster way (Figure S11 of the ).
elements.clean_text: In structural terms, InOF-8 showcases one-dimensional hexagonal channels divided by tetrahedral Cu4I4 and [In3O(CO2)6] moieties. The interconnection of six Cu4I4 units and six [In3O(CO2)6] units makes up the cross section of the hexagonal channel with a maximal size of 18.9 Å by the internal edge of two opposite Cu4I4 and 36.1 Å by the external edge of opposite [In3O(CO2)6] forms along the c axis, respectively, as shown in Figure c. There is a small cage-based cavity between two [In3O(CO2)6] moieties along the c axis, which is interconnected by three Cu4I4 clusters, two [In3O(CO2)6] moieties, and six nia- ligands, with a 4.8 Å diameter sphere (Figure b). Therefore, the overall structure of InOF-8 is a highly porous MOF structure in which cages and one-dimensional channels coexist in a cluster-by-cluster way (Figure S11 of the ).

elements.content: In summary, via the introduction of functional Cu-based units into an indium–organic framework by the bifunctional method for the first time, a series of three-dimensional functional InOF materials have been successfully obtained and structurally characterized. Bulky cluster-based Cu4I4 moieties can effectively prevent penetration for InOF-6, -7, and -8. Moreover, their gas sorption behavior has also been studied. On the other hand, we have also successfully obtained novel lanthanide–organic frameworks (Ln-MOFs) with transition metal units through the bifunctional method, and this work is ongoing.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In summary, via the introduction of functional Cu-based units into an indium-organic framework by the bifunctional method for the first time, a series of three-dimensional functional InOF materials have been successfully obtained and structurally characterized. Bulky cluster-based Cu4I4 moieties can effectively prevent penetration for InOF-6, -7, and -8. Moreover, their gas sorption behavior has also been studied. On the other hand, we have also successfully obtained novel lanthanide-organic frameworks (Ln-MOFs) with transition metal units through the bifunctional method, and this work is ongoing.

elements.content: Crystallographic data in CIF format, supplementary crystal structure figures, electron paramagnetic resonance data, TGA and PXRD patterns, and gas sorption data of these as-made InOF crystals. This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.
elements.clean_text: Crystallographic data in CIF format, supplementary crystal structure figures, electron paramagnetic resonance data, TGA and PXRD patterns, and gas sorption data of these as-made InOF crystals. This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.

References

cln_elements.content:
A mixture of In(NO3)3 (0.10 mmol, 33 mg), CuI (0.20 mmol, 38 mg), and Hnic (0.20 mmol, 25 mg, Hnic = isonicotinic acid) in an N,N′-dimethylacetamide (DMA, 3 mL)/MeCN (3 mL) mixed solvent was sealed in an autoclave, which was heated at 120 °C for 3 days and cooled to room temperature. Single-crystal electron paramagnetic resonance data confirmed the Cu(II) ions in the framework formulation of [InCu(inc)4](NO3) (Figure S12 of the ). After being washed with fresh MeCN, the orange crystals were obtained in ∼55% yield based on the Hnic ligand. Elemental analysis was conducted for InOF-5: C, 41.64%; H, 3.19%; N, 10.88%. Found: C, 41.58%; H, 3.12%; N, 10.41%. Finally, the phase purity of the sample was confirmed by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) (Figure S13 of the ).

Synthesis of [Me<sub>2</sub>NH<sub>2</sub>]<sub>2</sub>[In<sub>2</sub>(Cu<sub>4</sub>I<sub>4</sub>)(pdc)<sub>4</sub>]·0.25Dioxane·0.25DMA·0.25DMPU (<bold>InOF-6</bold>)

A mixture of InCl3 (0.10 mmol, 23 mg), CuI (0.20 mmol, 38 mg), and H2pdc (0.10 mmol, 17 mg, H2pdc = 3,5-pyridinedicarboxylic acid) in a DMA (3 mL)/N,N′-dimethylpropyleneurea (DMPU, 2 mL)/1,4-dioxane (2 mL) mixed solvent was sealed in a 23 mL glass vial, which was heated at 120 °C for 4 days and cooled to room temperature. As for the charge equilibrium, the DMA solvent molecules were decomposed into disordered Me2NH2 + cations during the reaction. After being washed with fresh MeCN, the light yellow crystals were obtained in ∼40% yield based on the H2pdc ligand. Elemental analysis was conducted for InOF-6: C, 23.43%; H, 1.95%; N, 5.20%. Found: C, 23.48%; H, 2.04%; N, 5.16%. The phase purity was confirmed by PXRD (Figure S13 of the ).

Synthesis of [In<sub>2</sub>(Cu<sub>4</sub>I<sub>4</sub>)(OH)<sub>2</sub>(nia)<sub>4</sub>]·2EtOH·DMA (<bold>InOF-7</bold>)

A mixture of In(NO3)3 (0.10 mmol, 33 mg), CuI (0.20 mmol, 38 mg), and Hnia (0.40 mmol, 49 mg, Hnia = nicotinic acid) in a DMA (3 mL)/EtOH (3 mL) mixed solvent was sealed in an autoclave, which was heated at 120 °C for 7 days and cooled to room temperature. After being washed with fresh MeCN, the colorless crystals were obtained in ∼50% yield based on the organic ligand. Elemental analysis was conducted for InOF-7: C, 22.70%; H, 2.32%; N, 4.14%. Found: C, 22.58%; H, 2.23%; N, 4.16%. The phase purity of the sample was also confirmed by PXRD (Figure S13 of the ).

Synthesis of [(In<sub>3</sub>O)<sub>2</sub>(Cu<sub>4</sub>I<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>(nia)<sub>12</sub>(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>6</sub>](NO<sub>3</sub>)<sub>2</sub>·12MeCN·DMA (<bold>InOF-8</bold>)

A mixture of In(NO3)3 (0.10 mmol, 33 mg), CuI (0.20 mmol, 38 mg), and Hnia (0.40 mmol, 49 mg) in a DMA (3 mL)/MeCN (3 mL) mixed solvent was sealed in an autoclave, which was heated at 120 °C for 7 days and cooled to room temperature. It is worth noting that there are disordered charge-balancing NO3– anions stored inside the large solvent accessible void, which is squeezed out. After being washed with fresh MeCN, the colorless crystals of InOF-8 were obtained in ∼33% yield based on the organic ligand. Elemental analysis was conducted for InOF-8: C, 22.73%; H, 2.00%; N, 7.16%. Found: C, 22.59%; H, 2.07%; N, 7.20%. The phase purity of the sample was also confirmed by PXRD (Figure S13 of the ).
cln_elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of [InCu(inc)4](NO3)⋅0.5MeCN⋅DMA (InOF-5)

A mixture of In(NO3)3 (0.10 mmol, 33 mg), CuI (0.20 mmol, 38 mg), and Hnic (0.20 mmol, 25 mg, Hnic = isonicotinic acid) in an N,N'-dimethylacetamide (DMA, 3 mL)/MeCN (3 mL) mixed solvent was sealed in an autoclave, which was heated at 120 °C for 3 days and cooled to room temperature. Single-crystal electron paramagnetic resonance data confirmed the Cu(II) ions in the framework formulation of [InCu(inc)4](NO3) (Figure S12 of the ). After being washed with fresh MeCN, the orange crystals were obtained in ~55% yield based on the Hnic ligand. Elemental analysis was conducted for InOF-5: C, 41.64%; H, 3.19%; N, 10.88%. Found: C, 41.58%; H, 3.12%; N, 10.41%. Finally, the phase purity of the sample was confirmed by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) (Figure S13 of the ).

Synthesis of [Me2NH2]2[In2(Cu4I4)(pdc)4]⋅0.25Dioxane⋅0.25DMA⋅0.25DMPU (InOF-6)

A mixture of InCl3 (0.10 mmol, 23 mg), CuI (0.20 mmol, 38 mg), and H2pdc (0.10 mmol, 17 mg, H2pdc = 3,5-pyridinedicarboxylic acid) in a DMA (3 mL)/N,N'-dimethylpropyleneurea (DMPU, 2 mL)/1,4-dioxane (2 mL) mixed solvent was sealed in a 23 mL glass vial, which was heated at 120 °C for 4 days and cooled to room temperature. As for the charge equilibrium, the DMA solvent molecules were decomposed into disordered Me2NH2 + cations during the reaction. After being washed with fresh MeCN, the light yellow crystals were obtained in ~40% yield based on the H2pdc ligand. Elemental analysis was conducted for InOF-6: C, 23.43%; H, 1.95%; N, 5.20%. Found: C, 23.48%; H, 2.04%; N, 5.16%. The phase purity was confirmed by PXRD (Figure S13 of the ).

Synthesis of [In2(Cu4I4)(OH)2(nia)4]⋅2EtOH⋅DMA (InOF-7)

A mixture of In(NO3)3 (0.10 mmol, 33 mg), CuI (0.20 mmol, 38 mg), and Hnia (0.40 mmol, 49 mg, Hnia = nicotinic acid) in a DMA (3 mL)/EtOH (3 mL) mixed solvent was sealed in an autoclave, which was heated at 120 °C for 7 days and cooled to room temperature. After being washed with fresh MeCN, the colorless crystals were obtained in ~50% yield based on the organic ligand. Elemental analysis was conducted for InOF-7: C, 22.70%; H, 2.32%; N, 4.14%. Found: C, 22.58%; H, 2.23%; N, 4.16%. The phase purity of the sample was also confirmed by PXRD (Figure S13 of the ).

Synthesis of [(In3O)2(Cu4I4)3(nia)12(H2O)6](NO3)2⋅12MeCN⋅DMA (InOF-8)

A mixture of In(NO3)3 (0.10 mmol, 33 mg), CuI (0.20 mmol, 38 mg), and Hnia (0.40 mmol, 49 mg) in a DMA (3 mL)/MeCN (3 mL) mixed solvent was sealed in an autoclave, which was heated at 120 °C for 7 days and cooled to room temperature. It is worth noting that there are disordered charge-balancing NO3- anions stored inside the large solvent accessible void, which is squeezed out. After being washed with fresh MeCN, the colorless crystals of InOF-8 were obtained in ~33% yield based on the organic ligand. Elemental analysis was conducted for InOF-8: C, 22.73%; H, 2.00%; N, 7.16%. Found: C, 22.59%; H, 2.07%; N, 7.20%. The phase purity of the sample was also confirmed by PXRD (Figure S13 of the ).

cln_elements.content:
Although the ctn-type InOF-6 contains no straight channels (Figure c), a large guest accessible pore volume is still available after the removal of guest molecules, and the free volume is calculated to be 4403.7 Å3 per unit cell volume and the potential porosity 58.1% by the PLATON program using the default probe size. Meanwhile, the diameter of the largest sphere that can be implanted in this three-dimensional cage-based framework without surpassing the internal surfaces of frameworks is approximately 5.6 Å, while the outermost I···I distance in the cage-based model is ∼21.7 Å as shown in Figure b. The desolvated material exhibits a quasi-type I N2 isotherm with a saturated uptake of 42.4 cm3 g–1 at 77 K, and its BET, Langmuir surface areas, and specific pore volume are 89.8 m2 g–1, 113.2 m2 g–1, and 0.066 cm3 g–1, respectively (Figure S17 of the ).

By linking the Cu4I4 clusters and μ2-OH– by the bifunctional nia– ligands coordinated with In(III) centers to form an infinite In–OH–In–OH chain running along the c axis, InOF-7 exhibits an overall 3D microporous framework (Figure c). The entire structure possesses one-dimensional narrow rhombus-like channels with an aperture size of 12.9 Å × 12.9 Å into which can be inserted 5.5 Å cylinders (Figure S8 of the ). Meanwhile, another interesting structural characteristic is the chain-by-cluster-by-chain structure constructed from functional tetrahedral Cu4I4 clusters and infinite In(OH)(CO2)2 chains (Figure b). Although not all InO chains are parallel to each other in InOF-7, the shortest distance observed between two neighboring InO chains is approximately 16.2 Å (Figure c). In addition, the pore volume ratio is calculated to be 42.0% [per unit cell volume (22363.0 Å3)]; the total free volume is 9400.6 Å3 after the removal of those redundant guest solvent molecules. After the activation process, the experimental N2 sorption isotherm at 77 K confirms its retention of microporosity with a maximal uptake of 155.3 cm3 g–1. Its BET, Langmuir surface area, and real pore volume are 526.6 m2 g–1, 637.4 m2 g–1, and 0.240 cm3 g–1, respectively (Figure S18 of the ).

Meanwhile, the diameter of the largest sphere that can be implanted in this three-dimensional cage-based framework without surpassing the internal surfaces of frameworks is approximately 5.6 Å, while the outermost I⋅⋅⋅I distance in the cage-based model is ~21.7 Å as shown in Figure b. The desolvated material exhibits a quasi-type I N2 isotherm with a saturated uptake of 42.4 cm3 g-1 at 77 K, and its BET, Langmuir surface areas, and specific pore volume are 89.8 m2 g-1, 113.2 m2 g-1, and 0.066 cm3 g-1, respectively (Figure S17 of the ).

By linking the Cu4I4 clusters and μ2-OH- by the bifunctional nia- ligands coordinated with In(III) centers to form an infinite In-OH-In-OH chain running along the c axis, InOF-7 exhibits an overall 3D microporous framework (Figure c). Summary of Crystal Data and Refinement Results crystal formula of framework space group a (Å) b (Å) c (Å) α, β (deg) γ (deg) V (Å3) InOF-5 [InCu(inc)4](NO3) Fddd 12.2035(3) 22.5755(6) 24.7498(5) 90 90 6818.6(3) InOF-6 [Me2NH2]2[In2(Cu4I4)(pdc)4] I4̅2d 20.338(3) 20.338(3) 18.381(5) 90 90 7603(3) InOF-7 [In2(Cu4I4)(OH)2(nia)4] Fddd 59.030(4) 23.417(2) 16.1795(7) 90 90 22363(3) InOF-8 [(In3O)2(Cu4I4)3(nia)12(H2O)6](NO3)2 P6/mcc 21.9173(4) 21.9173(4) 28.2685(4) 90 120 11760.0(3)

InOF denotes an indium–organic framework.

Abbreviations: Hinc, isonicotinic acid; Hnia, nicotinic acid; H2pdc, 3,5-pyridinedicarboxylic acid.

| crystal[^a] | formula of framework[^b] | space group | a (Å)    | b (Å)    | c (Å)    | α, β (deg) | γ (deg) | V (Å³)    |
|-------------|---------------------------|-------------|----------|----------|----------|------------|---------|-----------|
| InOF-5      | [InCu(inc)₄](NO₃)          | Fddd        | 12.2035(3) | 22.5755(6) | 24.7498(5) | 90         | 90      | 6818.6(3) |
| InOF-6      | [Me₂NH₂]₂[In₂(Cu₄I₄)(pdc)₄] | I4̅2d        | 20.338(3) | 20.338(3) | 18.381(5) | 90         | 90      | 7603(3)   |
| InOF-7      | [In₂(Cu₄I₄)(OH)₂(nia)₄]    | Fddd        | 59.030(4) | 23.417(2) | 16.1795(7) | 90         | 90      | 22363(3)  |
| InOF-8      | [(In₃O)₂(Cu₄I₄)₃(nia)₁₂(H₂O)₆](NO₃)₂ | P6/mcc | 21.9173(4) | 21.9173(4) | 28.2685(4) | 90         | 120     | 11760.0(3) |

[^a]: InOF denotes an indium–organic framework.
[^b]: Abbreviations: Hinc, isonicotinic acid; Hnia, nicotinic acid; H2pdc, 3,5-pyridinedicarboxylic acid.
<END>
